review.title: The Role of Normalization in the Belief Propagation Algorithm
review.abstract: An important part of problems in statistical physics and computer science can be expressed as the computation of marginal probabilities over a Markov Random Field. The belief propagation algorithm, which is an exact procedure to compute these marginals when the underlying graph is a tree, has gained its popularity as an efficient way to approximate them in the more general case. In this paper, we focus on an aspect of the algorithm that did not get that much attention in the literature, which is the effect of the normalization of the messages. We show in particular that, for a large class of normalization strategies, it is possible to focus only on belief convergence. Following this, we express the necessary and sufficient conditions for local stability of a fixed point in terms of the graph structure and the beliefs values at the fixed point. We also explicit some connexion between the normalization constants and the underlying Bethe Free Energy.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: The motivation of this work was to fill a gap in the literature on the effects of normalization on the BP algorithm. What we have learned can be summarized in a few key points. • The use of normalization in BP can in some rare cases kill or create new points of reference. • Not all normalizations are created equal when it comes to the convergence of messages, but there is a large category of positive homogeneous normalization, all of which have the same effect. • The user is ultimately preoccupied with the convergence of beliefs, and fortunately the dynamics of normalized beliefs are insensitive to normalization.
